body: We have not seen this issue (and many people have successfully used the refinement steps). Can you please submit a minimal working example?

I am facing the same problem too. 

 OS: windows 10
 DLC : 2.0

When I use analyze_video, the programme cannot finish with 100%, but with 60%(6:33 min) ,95%(4:33 min) or lower. I searched on the user forum, and be suggested that to use CMD instead of IDE and use GPU. I tried, but analyse_video() still cannot reach 100% completion. 
   So the analyzed results might miss some frames due to the unfinished analyze_video() results. The index extracted in extract_outlier_frames() might not be consistent with the frames in the original video.

Hi @AlexEMG 
I think I have a clue on why machine labeled (after selecting outliers) frames have wrong coordinates. 

The machinelabel.h5 or .csv have the right coordinates, however, somehow, when it gets written in the collecteddata.h5/.csv the indexing are wrong, thus when viewing the frames, the labels have the coordinates of another frame, and also if the right frame doesn't have a body part, in the wrong frame it won't show the body part. 

A minimal working example would just be to select outlier frames, save 5 frames, run refine labels, there is where problems arise, if I am on the 2nd frame [1] and go back to the first [0], I can go back even more to -n frame.
I tried to run it on my mac, and the same problem appeared. 
Is that more clear?

below is an example with index -1 (masked the face for privacy). The labels belong to another frame, and in this case there should be left-hand labels:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17873774/73807728-6f3d1b00-479b-11ea-84f8-b7bfac06b2c0.png)

Here is an example of 64% analyzed video, which generates missing frames labeled video after create_labeled_video()
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23357454/73814155-29c13200-481d-11ea-9789-b819e8bbcfc6.png)

@FancyBrush yes I believe your issue is because the analyzed frames are not matching the video. Thanks for clarifying you did you used "labeled.mp4". You should try another video; if it is corrupt this will not work. I don't know how to fix corrupt videos, as often the metadata is broken.

@MMathisLab 
Another two .avi videos still can not be fully analyzed, but with 93% and 94% completion.

@MMathisLab 
Sorry for bothering, there is an condition I forgot, which is the input .avi is generated from a .wmv video by a videotype transformation software. If the .avi file is corrupt, is .wmv a suitable video type for DeepLabCut?

In general both types are fine, just your specific video seems to be corrupt. (Try to load all frames with cv2)

________________________________
